main.description: has calculated which political party wants to put how much money in whose wallet. Now see what's in it for you.

terms.paper-title: Reformvorschläge der Parteien zur Bundestagswahl 2025: Finanzielle Auswirkungen
terms.paper-author: (ZEW – Leibniz-Zentrum für Europäische Wirtschaftsforschung GmbH Mannheim)

questions.income-group: What is your gross income in Euros?
questions.income-group-year: What is your gross annual income in Euros?
questions.income-group-month: or what is your gross monthly income in Euros?
questions.parties: Which political parties would you like to consider?
questions.results-format: How should the results be presented?
questions.why-dont-i-see-the-afd: Why don't I see the AfD?

labels.absolute-income-change-monthly: absolute change in disposable income per month
labels.absolute-income-change-annually: absolute change in disposable income per year

context.disposable-income: The disposable income describes the amount that actually ends up in your account. It is made up of your gross income minus taxes and contributions (= net income) and plus any transfer payments (such as child benefit, housing benefit or citizen's allowance).
context.no-afd: The authors of this page have decided not to include the proposals of the AfD party, which is partly on the extreme right. Only parties that are credibly committed to democracy, the rule of law and human dignity are shown on this page. The AfD's unfunded promises, which clearly favor wealthy and rich people, can be found in the original ZEW study if you are interested.
